## Introduction

We have learned that a verb must have a doer in the u-state and can have a direct doee in the a-state.
In this chapter, we will learn about a new type of verb, whose doer is called its subject, and whose direct doee is called its info.

The principal verb of this type is [كَانَ]{.ar} which is used to mean "was". There are other verbs which behave in a similar manner and they are called the _sisters_ of [كَانَ]{.ar}.


## [كَانَ]{.ar} as a deficient verb

In chapter\ (gov), we learned that a verbal sentence is formed from a verb and its doer.
The verb constitutes the structure-completer and its doer constitutes the structure-starter.
For example:

(@kaana_qaama_zaydun) [قَامَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd stood up.]{.trans}  

In example (@kaana_qaama_zaydun)  above
[قَامَ]{.ar} is the structure-completer and
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is the structure-starter.

Most verbs behave in this manner.
They are termed _sufficient_ verbs
because the verb contains sufficient meaning to be the structure-completer by expressing some property about its doer (the structure-starter).

There are some verbs, however, that do not contain sufficient meaning to be the structure-completer of a sentence.
These verbs are termed _deficient_ verbs.
For such verbs, the verb's direct doee is needed to complete the meaning of the sentence.
The verb
[كَانَ]{.ar}, which means "[was]{.trans}", is one such verb.
If we say
[كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
[Zayd was]{.trans}
then the meaning is, in general, incomplete.
The listener would be left wondering,
[Zayd was what?]{.trans}
<!--
[كَانَ]{.ar},
and verbs like it,
are termed deficient verbs.
-->
So,
in order
to complete the meaning of the sentence,
we have to add a direct doee for [كَانَ]{.ar}.
For example:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}
    [Peled, _Sentence types_ 171]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was standing]{.trans}  

Now the sentence is structurally complete.

<!--
In example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) 
the doer
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
is the structure-starter, as usual.
But the structure-completer is not the verb
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
Rather it is the direct doee
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}.
-->

## A [كَانَ]{.ar} sentence as a nounal sentence

The fact that [كَانَ]{.ar} is not a indispensable element of its sentence
also changes the classification of the sentence.
The structure-starter
in example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman)
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
needs
a structure-completer to complete the sentence.
Because
the  verb
[كَانَ]{.ar}
does not complete the meaning of the sentence,
therefore
it cannot be the structure-completer.
The sentence becomes structurally complete when we add the direct doee
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}.
Therefore, the direct doee
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}
is the structure-completer.

So indispensable elements in example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) become
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
(the structure-starter)
and 
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}
(the structure-completer).
These two are nouns, not a verb and its doer.
Therefore the sentence is reclassified as a nounal sentence, not a verbal sentence
(see section\ (3amal)).^[See also Peled, _Sentence types_ 171]
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
is considered the subject,
and 
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}
is considered the info.^[This is according to the classification of the [#baSr]{.trn2}ans. The [#kUf]{.trn2}ans considered the a-state governee of [كَانَ]{.ar} its [HAl]{.trn2}. See [[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للشاطبي]{.ar}\ 2/137](https://shamela.ws/book/20562/798#p1)]

Although
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is not a indispensable element anymore,
it still governs both indispensable elements.
Therefore, it is the foundational government of the sentence (see section\ (ref)).

Therefore, the sentence is a nounal sentence, not a verbal sentence

We leaned in section\ (ref) that the indispensable elements of a nounal sentence are its subject and its info.
So now that a [كَانَ]{.ar} sentence is reclassified as a nounal sentence,
we also rename its indispensable elements.
The doer of [كَانَ]{.ar} is termed its subject.
And the direct doee of [كَانَ]{.ar} is termed its info.

## Word order of [كَانَ]{.ar}, its subject, and its info

<!--
### Word order when [كَانَ]{.ar}'s info does not have a direct doee
-->

#### Verb, subject, info {.unnumbered}

In sentence word order, the natural sequence is 
verb, subject, info.

@) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}
  [Wright 2/100B]{.citex}  
  [Zayd was standing.]{.trans}  

#### Verb, info, subject {.unnumbered}

The sequence verb, info, subject is also permissible.

(@ex000289) [كَانَ قَائِمًا زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/100B]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was standing.]{.trans}

#### Info, verb, subject {.unnumbered}

So is the sequence info, verb, subject:

(@ex000290) [قَائِمًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/100B]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was standing.]{.trans}

This last order is common in questions and alternative sentence sentences.^[Wright 2/100B]
For example:

(@ex000291) [أَقَائِمًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    [Was Zayd standing?]{.trans}

(@ex000292) [أَكْرِمْ الضَّيْفَ غَنِيًّا كَانَ أَوْ فَقِيرًا]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/100B]{.citex}  
    [Honor the guest, be he rich or poor.]{.trans}  

Sometimes, however, this inversion is impossible because of an indistinguishable state of the two nouns.

For example, in order to express [My brother was my companion,]{.trans} we must say:

(@ex000293) [كَانَ أَخِي رَفِيقِي]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/100C]{.citex}  
    [My brother was my companion.]{.trans}

This is because, if we invert it, it would naturally mean:

(@ex000294) [كَانَ رَفِيقِي أَخِي]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/100C]{.citex}  
    [My companion was my brother.]{.trans}

#### Subject, verb, info {.unnumbered}

What about the sequence: subject, verb, info? For example:

(@ex000295) [زَيْدٌ كَانَ قَائِمًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd -- he was standing.]{.trans}

Remember that a verb must be followed by its doer.
So this is actually a compound sentence.
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar} is the subject of the outer sentence.
And the info of the outer sentence is the inner sentence
[كَانَ قَائِمًا]{.ar}.
The subject of [كَانَ]{.ar} is a latent pronoun, implicated a [[هُوَ]]{.ar}.

#### Word order when [كَانَ]{.ar}'s info has a a-state governee {.unnumbered}

We know from chapter\ (ref) that a deverbal noun can have a doee.
The natural word order is for this doee to occur after its governor, thus:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_aakilan_ta3aamaka) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ]{.ar} [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was eating your food.]{.trans}  

Other word orders are also possible.
We will discuss the different combinations below:

(@ex000296) Basic order: [كَانَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا]{.ar}  
    (a) ✓ [كَانَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}  
    (c) ✓ [كَانَ زَيْدٌ طَعَامَكَ آكِلًا]{.ar}  
    (d) ✓ [طَعَامَكَ كَانَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا]{.ar}  
    (b) ✗ [كَانَ طَعَامَكَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا]{.ar}  

(@ex000297) Basic order: [كَانَ آكِلًا زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (a) ✓ [كَانَ آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (b) ✓ [كَانَ آكِلًا زَيْدٌ طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}  
    (d) ✓ [طَعَامَكَ كَانَ آكِلًا زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (c) ✗ [كَانَ طَعَامَكَ آكِلًا زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  

(@kaana_aakilan_kaana_zaydun) Basic order: [آكِلًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (a) ✓ [آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (b) ✓ [طَعَامَكَ آكِلًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    (c) ✓ [آكِلًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}  
    (d) ✗ [آكِلًا كَانَ طَعَامَكَ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  

As you can see, only three of the combinations are disallowed.^[There is some difference of opinion regarding the permissibility of some of the combinations. See [شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar}\ 1/280; [الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59; [الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 1/432.]
And in all three 
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
is separated
from its subject 
([زَيْدٌ]{.ar} )
by the governee
([طَعَامَكَ]{.ar})
of its info
([آكِلًا]{.ar}).

Even some of these disallowed combinations become permitted 
if the governee of the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
is not a direct doee
but a preposition or an adverb of time and place.
Recall from section\ (ref)
that the word order of prepositions and adverbs of time and place is especially flexible.
So we can say:

(@ex000298) [كَانَ عِنْدَكَ زَيْدٌ مُقِيمًا]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar}\ 1/280]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was, at your place, staying.]{.trans}

(@ex000299) [كَانَ فِيكَ زَيْدٌ رَاغِبًا]{.ar}
    [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar}\ 1/280]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was, of [your favour], desirous]{.trans}

Some of the combinations above, though allowed, are considered ungainly by some grammarians^[[الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 1/432],
like (@kaana_aakilan_kaana_zaydun)\ (3)\ [آكِلًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}.
But again,
if the governee of the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
is not a direct doee
but a preposition or an adverb of time and place,
then there is no problem.
For example:

(@ex000300) [مُسَافِرًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ الْيَوْمَ]{.ar}
    [[الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 1/432]{.citex}  
    [Journeying Zayd was today]{.trans}  

(@ex000301) [رَاغِبًا كَانَ زَيْدٌ فِيكَ]{.ar}
    [[الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 1/432]{.citex}  
    [Desirous Zayd was, of [your favour]]{.trans}  

#### Word order of a compound sentence when [كَانَ]{.ar}'s info has a a-state governee {.unnumbered}

The subject can made to precede [كَانَ]{.ar}, such that it becomes a compound sentence:

(@ex000302) [زَيْدٌ كَانَ آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}
    [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59]{.citex}  

Now the subject of [كَانَ]{.ar} is a latent pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}].
Since this latent pronoun is attached to [كَانَ]{.ar},
the info [آكِلًا]{.ar}'s governee [طَعَامَك]{.ar} can no longer come between [كَانَ]{.ar} and its subject.
Now all twelve combinations are permissible.^[inferred from [الهمع للسيوطي]{.ar} 1/433],
Here is a sampling out of them:

(@ex000303) (a) [طَعَامَكَ زَيْدٌ كَانَ آكِلًا]{.ar}   [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59]{.citex}  
    (a) [زَيْدٌ طَعَامَكَ آكِلًا كَانَ]{.ar}   [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59]{.citex}  
    (a) [طَعَامَكَ آكِلًا زَيْدٌ كَانَ]{.ar}   [[الأشباه والنظائر للسيوطي]{.ar}\ 2/59]{.citex}

## A pronoun as the info of [كَانَ]{.ar}

When a pronoun is the info of [كَانَ]{.ar},
then it may optionally be attached to 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
or separated using the prefix
[إِيَّا]{.ar}.

Examples:

(@ex000304) [إِنْ **يَكُنْهُ** فَلَنْ تُسَلَّطَ عَلَيْهِ وَإِنْ لَمْ **يَكُنْهُ** فَلاَ خَيْرَ لَكَ فِي قَتْلِهِ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2930a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2930a) cited by [[شرح الكافية الشافية لابن مالك]{.ar} 1/231](https://shamela.ws/book/12024/230#p1 )]{.citex}  
    [If he is he (i.e. the [#dajjAl]{.trn2}), you would not be able to overpower him, and if he is not he there is no good for you in killing him]{.trans}

(@ex000305) [الصَّدِيقُ كُنْتَهُ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/114](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/116)]{.citex}  
    [The friend -- you are he.]{.trans}  
    ([الصَّدِيقُ كُنْتَ إِيَّاهُ]{.ar} is also permitted.^[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 1/104, [النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/275])

(@ex000306) [كَانَهُ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[أوضح المسالك لابن هشام]{.ar} 1/114](https://shamela.ws/book/11825/116)]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was he.]{.trans}  

For the other sisters of [كَانَ]{.ar}
it is preferred that the pronoun be separated using the prefix
[إِيَّا]{.ar}.
An attached pronoun for the other sisters is rare.^[[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 2/245](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/573#p1)]

## A [maSdari Ean]{.trn2} as the subject or info of [كَانَ]{.ar}

Recall from chapter\ (ref) that
the clause of a [maSdari Ean]{.trn2} is equivalent to a [maSdar]{.trn2}, which is a noun.
Consider the following example:

<!--
(@ex000308) [فَمَا كَانَ جَوَابَ قَوۡمِهِۦۤ إِلَّاۤ أَن قَالُوا۟]{.quran}
    [[[سورة العنكبوت]{.ar} 29:24](https://quran.com/29/24) cited by [البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 714]{.citex}  
    [And the answer of his [i.e., Abraham's] people was not but that they said,]{.trans}  
-->

(@kaana_quran_6_23) [ثُمَّ لَمۡ تَكُن فِتۡنَتُهُمۡ إِلَّاۤ أَن قَالُوا۟ وَٱللَّهِ رَبِّنَا مَا كُنَّا مُشۡرِكِینَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأنعام]{.ar} 6:23](https://quran.com/6/23) cited by [البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 714]{.citex}  
    [Then there will be no [excuse upon] examination except they will say, "By Allāh, our Lord, we were not those who associated."]{.trans}  

The clause
[أَنْ قَالُوا]{.ar} is
equivalent to
[قَوْلُهُمْ]{.ar}
[their saying]{.trans}.
Due to this equivalence to a noun,
a [maSdari Ean]{.trn2} can be the subject or the info of [كَانَ]{.ar}.
For the [Ayah]{.trn2} in example (@kaana_quran_6_23),
[فِتْنَة]{.ar} is read in both 
the u-state 
([فِتْنَتُهُمْ]{.ar})
and the a-state
([فِتْنَتَهُمْ]{.ar})
in different recitations.^[[[القراءات العشر من الشاطبية والدرة — دار الصحابة]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/m-sahabah/6/23) for [سورة الأنعام]{.ar} 6:23]
So the 
[أَنْ قَالُوا]{.ar} clause 
is analyzed as the subject of [كَانَ]{.ar}
when
[فِتْنَة]{.ar} is read in the a-state as the info.
and it
is analyzed as the info of [كَانَ]{.ar}
when
[فِتْنَة]{.ar} is read in the u-state as the subject.

In general,
a [maSdari Ean]{.trn2} 
will be more likely to be 
the subject because is is considered more definite.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 715; [[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/3/147) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:147]

## A complete sentence as the info of [كَانَ]{.ar}

So far we have seen examples where the info of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is a single noun in the a-state.
In example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_aakilan_ta3aamaka) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ آكِلًا طَعَامَكَ]{.ar}
the info of the
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the noun
[آكِلًا]{.ar}.
The info [آكِلًا]{.ar} is governing a latent doer pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}] and the direct doee [طَعَامَكَ]{.ar},
but still, the info itself is a single noun, not a complete sentence.

Here is another example:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 662]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was setting out.]{.trans}  

In example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan) above
the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the noun
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}.

In section\ (ref),
we learned that the info of a nounal sentence can be a complete sentence.
So, the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
can be a complete sentence.
For example:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_aboohu_muntaliqun) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ أَبُوهُ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 692]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his father was setting out.]{.trans}  
    (literally: [Zayd was -- his father is setting out.]{.trans})

In example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_aboohu_muntaliqun),
the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the complete sentence
[أَبُوهُ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
[His father is setting out]{.trans}.
As we stated in section (ref),
when the info is a sentence, then internally it is governed independently with its own foundational government.
So
[كَانَ]{.ar}
has no governing effect _within_ the info sentence.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 683]
The inner sentence
[زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
has its own internal government with
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar} as the subject
and
[مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
as the info.
That is why
[مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
is in the u-state and not in the a-state.

The entire info sentence
[أَبُوهُ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
in in place of a a-state noun as the info of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}.

Here are some more examples of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
with a sentence as its info:

(@ex000309) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ أَخُوهُ ضَاحِكٌ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 692]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his brother was laughing.]{.trans}  


(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqun_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 692]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- setting out, his father was.]{.trans}  
    (literally: [Zayd was -- setting out, his father is.]{.trans})

In example,
(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqun_aboohu) above,
the sentence info is 
[مُنْطَلِقٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}.
[مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar} is the fronted info and
[أَبُوهُ]{.ar} is the subject.
Although this sentence is grammatically correct,
we will see in the next section that a sababi info is more likely to be used instead.

When [كَانَ]{.ar} has a info that is a complete sentence, then
the info of the inner sentence will match its subject in number and gender.
For example:

(@ex000310) [كَانَ الزَّيْدَانِ أَبَوَاهُمَا حَسَنَانِ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693]{.citex}  
    [The two Zayds -- their fathers [were] handsome.]{.trans}

(@ex000311) [كَانَ الزَّيْدَانِ حَسَنَانِ أَبَوَاهُمَا]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693 footnote 3]{.citex}  
    [The two Zayds -- handsome, their fathers [were].]{.trans}  
    (fronted info.)

(@ex000312) [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ حَسَنُونَ آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693 footnote 3]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds -- handsome, their fathers [were].]{.trans}  
    (sound plural as the fronted info.)

(@ex000313) [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ حِسَانٌ آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693 footnote 3]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds -- handsome, their fathers [were].]{.trans}  
    (broken plural as the fronted info.)

<!--
(@ex000314) [كَانَتْ هِنْدٌ أَخَوَاهُ ضَاحِكَانِ]{.ar}  
    [Hind -- her two brothers were laughing.]{.trans}  
-->

## A state-of-affairs pronoun as the subject of [كَانَ]{.ar}

[كَانَ]{.ar}
may have
a state-of-affairs pronoun as its subject.
And the info of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
will be an inner sentence.
For example

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaimun) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 745]{.citex}  
    [[The state of affairs] was -- Zayd is standing.]{.trans}  

In example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaimun) above,
the subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is a latent state-of-affairs pronoun [[هُوَ]{.ar}].
And the info of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the inner sentence
[زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar}
[Zayd is standing]{.trans}.
Compare example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaimun) with
example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar},
where
the subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is [زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
And the info of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the single element
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}.

Similarly, if the subject of the inner sentence is a feminine noun,
then the state-of-affairs pronoun subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is typically feminine, thus:

(@ex000315) [كَانَتْ هِنْدٌ قَائِمَةٌ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 745]{.citex}  
    [[The state of affairs] was -- Hind is standing.]{.trans}  

By the way, although the gender of the state-of-affairs pronoun usually matches the gender of the subject of its info, it is possible for it to mismatch.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 745, 746 footnote 1]
(We also mentioned this in section\ (ref).)

In practice, usage of the state-of-affairs pronoun in sentences like
example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaimun) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمٌ]{.ar} is uncommon, but nevertheless existent.^[See the analysis of the reading [فَكانَ أبَواهُ مُؤْمِنانِ]{.quran} in [[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/18/80) for [سورة الكهف]{.ar} 18:80]
Instead the construction in example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}
is far more likely to be used.
But,
as we will see in sections\ (ref) and (ref), if Allāh wills,
when the info of [كَانَ]{.ar} is a verbal sentence,
then the state-of-affairs pronoun is very commonly used as the subject of [كَانَ]{.ar}.

## [كَانَ]{.ar} with a sababi info

Consider again example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqun_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}.
Instead of using a sentence info,
we can reconstruct the sentence to have
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}
to be the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar},
and have
[أَبُوهُ]{.ar} as the doer of the doer participle
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}, thus:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقًا أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 692]{.citex}  
    [Zayd -- his father was setting out.]{.trans}  

This is a sababi info construction.
(See section\ (ref) for an introduction to the sababi info.)
The info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
in example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan_aboohu) above
is not a complete sentence.
Rather, it
is the single element 
[مُنْطَلِقًا]{.ar}.
A sentence with a sababi info like (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqan_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقًا أَبُوهُ]{.ar}
will be preferred over a sentence with a fronted info like (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_muntaliqun_aboohu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ مُنْطَلِقٌ أَبُوهُ]{.ar}.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 694]

When 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
has a sababi info,
then,
as mentioned in section\ (ref),
it generally remains singular regardless whether its doer is dual or plural.
So we get:

(@ex000316) [كَانَ الزَّيْدَانِ **مُنْطَلِقًا** أَبَوَاهُمَا]{.ar}  
    [The two Zayds -- their fathers [were] setting out.]{.trans}  

(@ex000317) [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ **مُنْطَلِقَةً** جَدَّاتُهُمْ]{.ar}  
    [The Zayds -- their grandmothers [were] setting out.]{.trans}  

But if the info has a broken plural, then it is permitted (and in fact preferred) to be used.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693]

(@ex000318) [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ **حِسَانًا** آبَاؤُهُمْ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 693]{.citex}  
    [The Zayds -- their fathers [were] handsome.]{.trans}  

## [كَانَ]{.ar} with a prepositional or adverbial info

It is possible for the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
to be
a prepositional or adverbial info.
For example:

(@ex000319) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ **فِي** الدَّارِ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 682]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was in the house.]{.trans}  

(@ex000320) [كَانَ مُحَمَّدٌ عِنْدَكَ]{.ar}
    [[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 682]{.citex}  
    [[#muHammad]{.trn2} was at your place.]{.trans}  

In such cases, the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is technically the implication of _general beingness_ 
[[مُسْتَقِرًّا]{.ar}]
(see section\ (ta3alluq)).
The implicated general beingness governs the preposition/adverb.
The preposition or adverb is not directly governed by
[كَانَ]{.ar}.^[[البسيط لابن أبي الربيع]{.ar} 682; But see the [tafsIr]{.trn2}s of [أَكَانَ لِلنَّاسِ عَجَبًا]{.quran} [[[سورة يونس]{.ar} 10:2](https://quran.com/10/2)] for a possible exception to this rule.]


## [كَانَ]{.ar} as a sufficient verb

As we mentioned in section\ (ref) above,
the verb [كَانَ]{.ar} that we have been using so far is called the _deficient_
[كَانَ]{.ar}.

There is another type of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
called the _sufficient_
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
This 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
has sufficient meaning to
not need an info.
The meaning that the sufficient 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
gives is the meaning of [exists]{.trans}.
In English, we usually express this meaning using [there was]{.trans}. For example,

(@ex000321) [كَانَ مَلِكٌ]{.ar}  
    [[There] was a king.]{.trans}  
    (literally: [A king was.]{.trans})

Note that [مَلِك]{.ar} [king]{.trans} is in the u-state as the subject.
If it were in the a-state, then it would change the meaning:

(@ex000322) [كَانَ مَلِكًا]{.ar}  
    [He was a king.]{.trans}

When
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is sufficient then it serves as the structure-completer.
So the sentence is a verbal sentence.

Here is another example of a sufficient [كَانَ]{.ar}:

(@kaana_kaana_taajirun) [كَانَ تَاجِرٌ وَكَانَ لَهُ بَنُونَ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/99D]{.citex}  
    [There was a trader, and he had sons.]{.trans}

Incidentally, 
in example (@kaana_kaana_taajirun),
the past verb of [have]{.trans}: [had]{.trans} is expressed using [كَانَ]{.ar} with the preposition [لِ]{.ar}.

## Significations of the perfect verb [كَانَ]{.ar}

The general siginification of the perfect verb 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is to indicate a state that existed in the past, and that has possibly ceased.
For example:

(@ex000323) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}  
    [Zayd was standing.]{.trans}

This statement is regarding Zayd's state in the past and the implication is that he is possibly no longer standing.

This is the most common signification of the perfect verb
[كَانَ]{.ar}
and the one that we have been using so far.
But
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is special in that it admits additional significations:

The second signification of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is to indicate a state that, at first, had not yet begun, and which then began and remained, possibly up to the present.
It has, in this sense, the meaning [became]{.trans}, [has become]{.trans}, or [happened]{.trans}. Examples:

(@ex000324) [أَبَىٰ وَٱسْتَكْبَرَ وَكَانَ مِنَ ٱلْكَـٰفِرِينَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:34](https://quran.com/2/34)]{.citex}  
    [He refused and was arrogant and became of the disbelievers.]{.trans}  

(@ex000325) [احْتَرَقَ الْخَشَبُ فَكَانَ تُرَابًا]{.ar}  
    [[النحو الوافي]{.ar} 1/548]{.citex}  
    [The wood burned and so became dust.]{.trans}

A third signification of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is
to indicate a state that will be in the future.
For example:

(@ex000326) [وَيَخَافُونَ يَوْمًۭا كَانَ شَرُّهُۥ مُسْتَطِيرًۭا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الإنسان]{.ar} 76:7](https://quran.com/76/7)]{.citex}  
    [and [they] fear a Day whose evil will be widespread.]{.trans}  

A fourth signification of 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is to indicate a state that always existed and will always exist.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/110) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:110]
For example:

(@ex000327) [وَكَانَ ٱللَّهُ غَفُورًۭا رَّحِيمًۢا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأحزاب]{.ar} 33:73](https://quran.com/33/73)]{.citex}  
    [And ever is Allāh Forgiving and Merciful.]{.trans}  

(@ex000328) [وَلَا تَقْرَبُوا۟ ٱلزِّنَىٰٓ ۖ إِنَّهُۥ كَانَ فَـٰحِشَةًۭ وَسَآءَ سَبِيلًۭا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الإسراء]{.ar} 17:32](https://quran.com/17/32)]{.citex}  
    [And do not approach unlawful sexual intercourse.1 Indeed, it is ever an immorality and is evil as a way.]{.trans}  

## Significations of the u-state stateful verb [يَكُونُ]{.ar}

### [يَكُونُ]{.ar} used for habitual [is]{.trans}

Consider the sentence, [The mother cooks the food.]{.trans} 
The verb [cooks]{.trans} implies that the action is habitually done, not necessarily that it is being done at present. 
If we wished to say that the action is being done at present, we might instead say, [The mother _is cooking_ the food.]{.trans}
English maintains this distinction between the present and the habitual for most verbs.
But it does not for ther verb [is]{.trans}.
So if we say, [The sky is blue,]{.trans} then it can mean both 
(i) that the sky is blue at present, or 
(ii) that it is habitually blue, not necessarily that it is blue at present.

In Arabic the situation is somewhat different.
Arabic does not usually have a distinction between the present and the habitual for most verbs. So [تَطْبُخُ الْأُمُّ الطَّعَامَ]{.ar}  may mean both
(i) that the mother is cooking the food at present, or
(ii) that she habitually does.

<!--However, interestingly, Arabic does have the distinction between the present and the habitual for the verb [is]{.trans}.
As you know, Arabic does not usually express a word for the present [is]{.trans}.-->
But for the verb [is]{.trans}, Arabic can distinguish between the present and the habitual.
So if we say [السَّمَاءُ زَرْقَاءُ]{.ar}, then this can, in general, mean both
(i) that the sky is blue at present, and
(ii) that it is habitually blue.
If we wish to specify the habitual meaning, we may use the stateful verb [يَكُونُ]{.ar}, thus:

(@ex000329) [تَكُونُ السَّمَاءُ زَرْقَاءَ]{.ar}  
    [The sky is (habitually) blue.]{.trans}

While we call this the 
habitual [يَكُونُ]{.ar},
it can include a range of meanings, including
continually, recurringly, regularly, typically, generally, often, sometimes, can, may, etc.
Habitual [يَكُونُ]{.ar} is negated using [مَا]{.ar} or [لَا]{.ar}, just like other u-state stateful verbs.

Here are some examples:

(@ex000330) [قَالَ وَمَا الْبِتْعُ وَالْمِزْرُ؟ قُلْتُ شَرَابٌ **يَكُونُ** مِنَ الْعَسَلِ وَالْمِزْرُ **يَكُونُ** مِنَ الشَّعِيرِ]{.ar}
    [[[سنن النسائي]{.ar} :5604](https://sunnah.com/nasai:5604)]{.citex}  
    [He said: 'What is mead and beer?' I said: 'A drink that **is** from honey, and beer **is** from barley.']{.trans}
<!--(From [سنن النسائي]{.ar}:5604)-->

(@ex000331) [إِنَّهَا **تَكُونُ** الظُّلْمَةُ وَالسَّيْلُ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :667](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:667)]{.citex}  
    [[There] **is [at times]** darkness and flooding]{.trans}  


<!--
[إِنَّ أَحَدَكُمْ لَيَعْمَلُ بِعَمَلِ أَهْلِ الْجَنَّةِ حَتَّى مَا يَكُونُ بَيْنَهُ وَبَيْنَهَا إِلاَّ ذِرَاعٌ]{.ar}  
[One of you will do deeds of the people of Paradise, until there is between him and it but a forearm span]{.trans}  
(Part of [HadIv]{.trn2} 2137 from [#jAmie al-#tirmipI]{.trn2})
From [جامع الترمذي]{.ar}:2137)-->
<!--
[يَكُونُ اللِّحَافُ وِسَادَةً وَلَا تَكُونُ الْوِسَادَةُ لِحَافًا]{.ar}  
[The blanket can be a pillow but the pillow cannot be a blanket.]{.trans}

[مَا يَكُونُ الرَّجُلُ صَدِيقَكَ حَتّى يَصْدُقَكَ]{.ar}  
[A man is not your friend until he is truthful to you.]{.trans}
-->

### [قَدْ يَكُونُ]{.ar} for [may be]{.trans}

When the meaning [may be]{.trans} is desired, the 
the stateful verb
[يَكُونُ]{.ar}
may be preceded by the particle [قَدْ]{.ar}. For example,

(@ex000332) [قَالَ أَبُو الدَّرْدَاء يَا رَسُولَ اللهِ يَسْرِقُ الْمُؤْمِنُ قَالَ قَدْ يَكُونُ ذَلكَ]{.ar}
    [https://hadithunlocked.com/suyuti:401-5b]{.citex}^[See <https://islamqa.info/ar/answers/264450> for the [taxrIj]{.trn2} of this [HadIv]{.trn2}.]  
    [[#abU al-#dardAE]{.trn2} said, "O Messenger of Allah, Can a believer steal?" He said, "That may be."]{.trans}

### [يَكُونُ]{.ar} used for future [will be]{.trans}

Another usage of the stateful verb
[يَكُونُ]{.ar}
is for the future tense to mean [will be]{.trans}.
In this case, it is often preceded by [سَ]{.ar} or [سَوْفَ]{.ar}.
[سَ]{.ar} and [سَوْفَ]{.ar} are optional and are commonly dropped, especially when the context indicates the future.
Future [يَكُونُ]{.ar}
is negated by [لَا]{.ar}.
Here are some examples:

(@ex000333) [فَقَدْ كَذَّبْتُمْ فَسَوْفَ يَكُونُ لِزَامًا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الفرقان]{.ar} 25:77](https://quran.com/25:77)]{.citex}  
    [For you [disbelievers] have denied, so it [i.e., your denial] is going to be adherent.]{.trans}  

(@ex000334) [لا يَكونُ اللَّعَّانُونَ شُفَعَاءَ وَلَا شُهَدَاءَ يَومَ القِيَامَةِ]{.ar}
    [[[رياض الصالحين]{.ar} :1553](https://sunnah.com/riyadussalihin:1553)]{.citex}  
    [The frequent cursers will be neither intercessors nor witnesses [on] the day of resurrection.]{.trans}  
    ([يَوْمَ]{.ar} is in the a-state because it is an adverb of time, see chapter\ \@ref(adverb-of-time).)

(@ex000335) [يَوْمَ يَكُونُ ٱلنَّاسُ كَٱلْفَرَاشِ ٱلْمَبْثُوثِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة القارعة]{.ar} 101:4](https://quran.com/101:4)]{.citex}  
    [It is the Day when people will be like moths, dispersed,]{.trans}  

(@ex000336) [يَكُونُ فِي آخِرِ الزَّمَانِ دَجَّالُونَ كَذَّابُونَ]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :7](https://sunnah.com/muslim:7)]{.citex}  
    [There will be in the end of time charlatan liars]{.trans}  

## Significance of the a-state stateful verb [يَكُونَ]{.ar}

Like a-state stateful verbs in general, [يَكُونَ]{.ar} [be]{.trans} expresses the meaning of purpose, wish, or expectation. It occurs after the particles
[أَنْ]{.ar},
[لَنْ]{.ar},
[لِ]{.ar},
[كَيْ]{.ar},
[حَتَّىٰ]{.ar}, and
[إِذَنْ]{.ar}.
All this is consistent with what we have learned about a-state stateful verbs in chapter\ \@ref(a-state-stateful-verbs).
Here are some examples:

(@ex000337) [نَزَلَ بِهِ ٱلرُّوحُ ٱلْأَمِينُ. عَلَىٰ قَلْبِكَ لِتَكُونَ مِنَ ٱلْمُنذِرِينَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الشعراء]{.ar} 26:193-194](https://quran.com/26/193-194)]{.citex}  
    [The Trustworthy Spirit [i.e., Gabriel] has brought it down. Upon your heart, [O Muḥammad] - that you may be of the warners -]{.trans}

(@ex000338) [لَّن يَسْتَنكِفَ ٱلْمَسِيحُ أَن يَكُونَ عَبْدًۭا لِّلَّهِ وَلَا ٱلْمَلَـٰٓئِكَةُ ٱلْمُقَرَّبُونَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة النساء]{.ar} 4:172](https://quran.com/4/172)]{.citex}  
    [Never would the Messiah disdain to be a servant of Allāh, nor would the angels near [to Him]]{.trans}

(@ex000339) [أَفَأَنتَ تُكْرِهُ ٱلنَّاسَ حَتَّىٰ يَكُونُوا۟ مُؤْمِنِينَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة يونس]{.ar} 10:99](https://quran.com/10/99)]{.citex}  
    [Then, [O Muḥammad], would you compel the people in order that they become believers?]{.trans}

## The 0-state stateful verb [يَكُنْ]{.ar} {#lam-yakun}

As with other verbs,
the 0-state stateful verb [يَكُنْ]{.ar} 
is used for negative commands, indirect commands, and with [لَمْ]{.ar} for negation, etc.
Examples:

(@ex000340) [**وَلْتَكُن** مِّنكُمْ أُمَّةٌۭ يَدْعُونَ إِلَى ٱلْخَيْرِ وَيَأْمُرُونَ بِٱلْمَعْرُوفِ وَيَنْهَوْنَ عَنِ ٱلْمُنكَرِ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:104](https://quran.com/3/104)]{.citex}  
    [And let there be [arising] from you a nation inviting to [all that is] good, enjoining what is right and forbidding what is wrong,1 and those will be the successful.]{.trans}

(@ex000341) [ٱلْحَقُّ مِن رَّبِّكَ فَلَا **تَكُن** مِّنَ ٱلْمُمْتَرِينَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:60](https://quran.com/3/60)]{.citex}  
    [The truth is from your Lord, so do not be among the doubters.]{.trans}

(@ex000342) [لَمْ **يَكُنِ** النَّبِيُّ صلى الله عليه وسلم سَبَّابًا وَلاَ فَحَّاشًا وَلاَ لَعَّانًا]{.ar}
    [[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :6031](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6031)]{.citex}  
    [The Prophet [ﷺ]{.aralt} was not one who would abuse (others) or say obscene words, or curse (others)]{.trans}

### Deletion of [ن]{.ar}

For the 0-state stateful conjugations of [كَانَ]{.ar} that don't have a [و]{.ar} between [ك]{.ar} and [ن]{.ar},
the [ن]{.ar} may optionally be deleted if certain conditions are satisfied.
These conjugations are:

+ [يَكُنْ]{.ar} which becomes [يَكُ]{.ar}
+ [تَكُنْ]{.ar} which becomes [تَكُ]{.ar}
+ [نَكُنْ]{.ar} which becomes [نَكُ]{.ar}
+ [أَكُنْ]{.ar} which becomes [أَكُ]{.ar}

These are the conditions, all of whom must be satisfied^[Conditions and examples taken from <https://github.com/zahidsyed/learning-nahw-analytically>]:

  i. The verb is not followed by a [sukUn]{.trn2}. Examples:

     (@) ✗ [لَمْ **يَكُ** الَّذِينَ ...]{.ar}  
         ✓ [لَمۡ **یَكُنِ** ٱلَّذِینَ كَفَرُوا۟ مِنۡ أَهۡلِ ٱلۡكِتَـٰبِ وَٱلۡمُشۡرِكِینَ مُنفَكِّینَ حَتَّىٰ تَأۡتِیَهُمُ ٱلۡبَیِّنَةُ]{.quran}
         [[[سورة البينة]{.ar} 98:1](https://quran.com/98/1)]{.citex}  
         [Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from misbelief]1 until there came to them clear evidence]{.trans}

     (@) ✗ [لَمْ **يَكُ** الرَّجُلُ حَاضِرًا]{.ar}  
         ✓ [لَمْ **يَكُنِ** الرَّجُلُ حَاضِرًا]{.ar}  
         [The man was not present.]{.trans}

 ii. The verb is not followed by an attached pronoun. Example:

     (@) ✗ [إِنْ **يَكُهُ** فَلَنْ ... وَإِنْ لَمْ **يَكُهُ** ...]{.ar}  
         ✓ [إِنْ **يَكُنْهُ** فَلَنْ تُسَلَّطَ عَلَيْهِ وَإِنْ لَمْ **يَكُنْهُ** فَلاَ خَيْرَ لَكَ فِي قَتْلِهِ]{.ar}
         [[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2930a](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2930a)]{.citex}  
         [If he is he (i.e. the [#dajjAl]{.trn2}), you would not be able to overpower him, and if he is not he there is no good for you in killing him]{.trans}

iii. The verb is not at the end of a sentence. Example:

     (@) ✗ [وَلَمْ **أَكُ**]{.ar}  
         ✓ [وَلَمۡ **أَكُ** بَغِیࣰّا]{.quran}
         [[[سورة مريم]{.ar} 19:20](https://quran.com/19/20)]{.citex}  
         [and I have not been unchaste]{.trans}

Here are some more examples which satisfy the conditions so the [ن]{.ar} is deleted.
Examples:

(@ex000343) [وَلَا **تَكُ** فِى ضَيْقٍۢ مِّمَّا يَمْكُرُونَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة النحل]{.ar} 16:127](https://quran.com/16/127)]{.citex}  
    [and do not be in distress over what they conspire.]{.trans}

(@ex000344) [وَقَدْ خَلَقْتُكَ مِن قَبْلُ وَلَمْ **تَكُ** شَيْـًۭٔا]{.quran}
    [[[سورة مريم]{.ar} 19:9](https://quran.com/19/9)]{.citex}  
    [for I created you before, while you were nothing]{.trans}

(@ex000345) [ قَالُوا۟ لَمۡ نَكُ مِنَ ٱلۡمُصَلِّینَ ۝٤٣ وَلَمۡ نَكُ نُطۡعِمُ ٱلۡمِسۡكِینَ ۝٤٤ ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة المدثر]{.ar} 74:43-44](https://quran.com/74/43-44)]{.citex}  
    [They will say, "We were not of those who prayed, Nor did we used to feed the poor.]{.trans}  

(@ex000346) [أَلَمۡ یَكُ نُطۡفَةࣰ مِّن مَّنِیࣲّ یُمۡنَىٰ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة القيامة]{.ar} 75:37](https://quran.com/75/37)]{.citex}  
    [Had he not been a sperm from semen emitted?]{.trans}

<!--
But we can't say:

(@ex000347) ✗ [لَمْ تَكُ ٱلرَّجُلَ]{.ar}  

This is because [ٱلرَّجُل]{.ar} begins with with a connecting hamzah [ٱ]{.ar}. So we have to say instead:

(@ex000348) [لَمْ تَكُنِ ٱلرَّجُلَ]{.ar}  
    [You were not the man.]{.trans}
-->

## The verb of command [كُنْ]{.ar} {#kun}

The verb of command [كُنْ]{.ar} is used to mean [Be!]{.trans}. Examples:

(@ex000349) [قُلْنَا يَـٰنَارُ كُونِى بَرْدًۭا وَسَلَـٰمًا عَلَىٰٓ إِبْرَٰهِيمَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة الأنبياء]{.ar} 21:69](https://quran.com/21:69)]{.citex}  
    We [i.e., Allāh] said, [O fire, be coolness and safety upon Abraham.]{.trans}  

(@ex000350) [فَقُلْنَا لَهُمْ كُونُوا۟ قِرَدَةً خَـٰسِـِٔينَ]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:65](https://quran.com/2:65)]{.citex}  
    "and We said to them, 'Be apes, despised.'  

The verb of command [كُنْ]{.ar} followed by the name of a person in the a-state is used to express one's guessing that the person whom one sees is the individual named. For example:

(@ex000351) [كُنْ أَبَا ذَرٍّ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/44C]{.citex}  
    [I presume that the person approaching is [#abU #parr]{.trn2}]{.trans}

(@ex000352) [كُنْ أَبَا زَيْدٍ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/44C]{.citex}  
    [I guess that you are [#abU]{.trn2} Zayd.]{.trans}


## The perfect verb [كَانَ]{.ar} combined with a stateful verb

In section\ (ref) above, we mentioned that the info
[كَانَ]{.ar}
can be a complete sentence.
The examples we gave were where the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
were nounal sentences.
<!--
One such example was (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_aboohu_muntaliqun) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ أَبُوهُ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
[Zayd -- his father was setting out.]{.trans}.
In this example the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the (complete) inner sentence
[أَبُوهُ مُنْطَلِقٌ]{.ar}
[His father is setting out]{.trans}.
-->

Instead of a nounal sentence as the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar},
the info is very often a verbal sentence.
[كَانَ]{.ar}
combined with verbal sentences to express complex tenses.
The most common combination is the perfect verb
[كَانَ]{.ar}
with a stateful verb in its info.

<!--
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is combined with a following stateful verb to express that the action of the verb was repeatedly or continually ocurring in the past.
-->
Consider again example (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman):

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}
    [Peled, _Sentence types_ 171]{.citex}  
    [Zayd was standing]{.trans}  

The info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is 
(as a single element)
the doer participle
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}.
Let's try to replace the doer participle
[قَائِمًا]{.ar}
with its stateful verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}.
We get:

(@kaana_kaana_zaydun_yaqoomu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd used to stand.]{.trans}  
    (literally: [Zayd was -- he stands.]{.trans})

<!--
We have translated (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_yaqoomu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}
as
[Zayd used to stand.]{.trans}.
And we translated (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_qaaiman) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ قَائِمًا]{.ar}
as
[Zayd was standing]{.trans}.
The exact difference in signification between the doer participle and its stateful verb is discussed in more detail in chapter\ (ref).
For now, we will say that,
in general,
-->
When
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is combined with a following stateful verb, or its doer participle,
it indicates an imperfect action that was occurring in the past.
The tense is usually either:

 i. Past-continuous ([he was doing]{.trans}), or
ii. Past-habitual ([he used to do]{.trans}).

In general,
[كَانَ]{.ar}
with a
stateful verb
can indicate either
tense.
Whereas
[كَانَ]{.ar}
with a doer participle
typically indicates the past-continuous tense.
The exact difference in signification between the doer participle and its stateful verb is discussed in more detail in chapter\ (ref).

Let's discuss the grammar of the new sentence
 (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_yaqoomu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}.
The subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
And
the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is the complete verbal sentence
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
[he stands]{.trans}.
The doer of the stateful verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
is the latent pronoun
[[هُوَ]{.ar}]
that refers back to the subject
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.

### The word order of [كَانَ]{.ar}, its subject, and the stateful verb {.unnumbered}

The sequence
([كَانَ]{.ar},
subject,
stateful verb)
is a very commonly used word order.
But there is also another word order which is also very frequently used.
And that is
([كَانَ]{.ar},
stateful verb,
subject).
For example:

(@kaana_kaana_yaqoomu_zaydun) [كَانَ يَقُومُ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd used to stand.]{.trans}  

There are two methods to anaylyze example (@kaana_kaana_yaqoomu_zaydun) above^[For details on the dispute amongst the grammarians on the parsing of this word order, see [[حاشية الصبان على شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 2/137](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/566); [[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 4/184](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/1198); [[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/7/137) for [سورة الأعراف]{.ar} 7:137 for [مَا كَانَ یَصۡنَعُ فِرۡعَوۡنُ]{.quran}; [[الدر المصون للسمين الحلبي]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/aldur-almasoon/9/117) for [سورة التوبة]{.ar} 9:117 for [مَا كَادَ یَزِیغُ قُلُوبُ فَرِیقࣲ مِّنۡهُمۡ]{.quran}]:

The first method is to consider
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
the doer of the stateful verb
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}.
The sentence
[يَقُومُ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
[Zayd stands]{.trans}
is then the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
And the subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is a latent state-of-affairs pronoun
[[هُوَ]{.ar}].
The state-of-affairs pronoun will typically go untranslated in this case.

The second method is to consider
[زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
the subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
The sentence
[يَقُومُ]{.ar}
[he stands]{.trans}
(with a latent doer pronoun)
is then the info of
[كَانَ]{.ar},
but which is made to precede its subject.
By the way, it seems that this second method is not used when the subject is dual or plural.
This is because we typically always find the stateful verb in the singular when it precedes the subject, regardless of whether the subject is singular, dual, or plural.
For example:

(@ex000353) ✓ [كَانَ يَقُومُ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    ✗ [كَانَ يَقُومَانِ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  
    [The two Zayds were standing.]{.trans}

Both word orders (@kaana_kaana_zaydun_yaqoomu) [كَانَ زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}
and (@kaana_kaana_yaqoomu_zaydun) [كَانَ يَقُومُ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}.
have,
more or less,
a similar meaning.

But choosing one of two word orders
can affect the conjugation of the stateful verb for dual and plural subjects.
Here is a table that compares conjugations for the two options:

|||
|:-----|:-----|
| [كَانَ زَيْدٌ يَقُومُ]{.ar}         | [كَانَ يَقُومُ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}      |
| [كَانَتْ هِنْدٌ تَقُومُ]{.ar}        | [كَانَتْ تَقُومُ هِنْدٌ]{.ar}     |
| [كَانَالزَّيْدَانِ يَقُومَانِ]{.ar}    | [كَانَ يَقُومُ الزَّيْدَانِ]{.ar}  |
| [كَانَتِ الْهِنْدَانِ تَقُومَانِ]{.ar}  | [كَانَتْ تَقُومُ الْهِنْدَانِ]{.ar} |
| [كَانَ الزَّيْدُونَ يَقُومُونَ]{.ar}   | [كَانَ يَقُومُ الزَّيْدُونَ]{.ar}  |
| [كَانَتِ الْهِنْدَاتُ يَقُمْنَ]{.ar}    | [كَانَتْ تَقُومُ الْهِنْدَاتُ]{.ar} |

When the subject of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is a dual or plural pronoun,
then it seems that only the
([كَانَ]{.ar},
subject,
stateful verb)
is used.
And the
([كَانَ]{.ar},
stateful verb,
subject)
is unused.
For example:

(@ex000354) ✓ [كَانُوا يَقُومُونَ]{.ar}  
    ✗ [كَانَ يَقُومُونَ]{.ar}  
    [They were standing.]{.trans}

Here are some more examples of [كَانَ]{.ar} followed by a stateful verb:

<!--[كَانَ يُحِبُّ ٱلشِّعْرَ وٱلشُّعَرَاءَ]{.ar}  
[He used to love poetry and the poets.]{.trans}
-->

[كَانَ يَعْبُدُ مُشْرِكُو مَكَّةَ ٱلْأَصْنَامَ]{.ar}  
or  
[كَانَ مُشْرِكُو مَكَّةَ يَعْبُدُونَ ٱلْأَصْنَامَ]{.ar}  
[The polytheists of Makkah used to worship idols.]{.trans}

[كَانَتْ تُحِبُّ الصَّدَقَةَ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :1420](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:1420)]{.citex}  
[She used to love [to practice] charity.]{.trans}

[كَانَت تَّأْتِيهِمْ رُسُلُهُم بِٱلْبَيِّنَـٰتِ]{.ar}
[[[سورة التغابن]{.ar} 64:6](https://quran.com/64:6)]{.citex}  
[their messengers used to come to them with clear evidences]{.trans}  
(Sound plurals, even of rational beings, may be treated as grammatically singular feminine. See section\ \@ref(sound-plurals-sing-fem).)

[كُنْتُ أَلْعَبُ بِالْبَنَاتِ عِنْدَ النَّبِيِّ صلى الله عليه وسلم وَكَانَ لِي صَوَاحِبُ يَلْعَبْنَ مَعِي]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :6130](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6130)]{.citex}  
[I used to play with dolls in the presence of the Prophet, and I had companions~f~ playing with me.]{.trans}

Occasionally, the particle [قَدْ]{.ar} precedes the combination of [كَانَ]{.ar} and the stateful verb. Example:

[قَالُوا هَذَا قَدْ كَانَ يَكْتُبُ لِمُحَمَّدٍ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2781](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2781)]{.citex}  
[They said, 'This [person] used to transcribe for [#muHammad]{.trn2} [ﷺ]{.aralt}']{.trans}

The following stateful verb may also be an passive verb. Example:

[إِنَّ أُنَاسًا كَانُوا يُؤْخَذُونَ بِالْوَحْىِ فِي عَهْدِ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :2641](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:2641)]{.citex}  
[Indeed people were (sometimes) judged (literally: held) by the [revealing of] divine inspiration in the lifetime of the Prophet.]{.trans}

### One [كَانَ]{.ar} suffices multiple stateful verbs

If the signification of an action ocurring continually in the past applies to more that one stateful verb, then it is sufficient to prefix 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
to only the first one. Example:

[كَانَتْ تَعْمَلُ بِيَدِهَا وَتَصَدَّقُ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :2452](https://sunnah.com/muslim:2452)]{.citex}  
[She used to work with her hand and spend (that income) on charity.]{.trans}  
([تَتَصَدَّقُ]{.ar} is abbreviated to [تَصَدَّقُ]{.ar}. See section\ \@ref(form-5-verbs-abbrev).)

### Negation of [كَانَ]{.ar} and a stateful verb

In order to negate the combination of
[كَانَ]{.ar}
and the following stateful verb,
multiple options are available. Using [يَفْعَلُ]{.ar} as an example stateful verb, we can have:

+ [مَا كَانَ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
+ [لَمْ يَكُنْ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
+ [كَانَ لَا يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}

Examples:

[مَا كَانَ أَحَدٌ يَبْدَأُ، أَوْ يَبْدُرُ، ابْنَ عُمَرَ بِالسَّلامِ]{.ar}
[[[الأدب المفرد]{.ar} :982](https://sunnah.com/adab:982)]{.citex}  
[No one preceded or got ahead of Ibn [#eumar]{.trn2} with (giving) the greeting.]{.trans}  

[كَانُوا۟ لَا يَتَنَاهَوْنَ عَن مُّنكَرٍۢ فَعَلُوهُ]{.ar}
[[[سورة المائدة]{.ar} 5:79](https://quran.com/5/79)]{.citex}  
[They used not to prevent one another from wrongdoing that they did.]{.trans}   

[لَمْ يَكُونُوا يَسْأَلُونَ عَنِ الإِسْنَادِ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :introduction](https://sunnah.com/muslim/introduction/26)]{.citex}  
[They would not ask about the chains of narration]{.trans}  

In terms of the differences between these constructions
[مَا كَانَ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
imparts more emphasis in the denial than
[كَانَ لَا يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}.

There is also difference between the options 
[مَا كَانَ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
and
[كَانَ لَا يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
in terms of when one would be used instead of the other.^[[معاني النحو]{.ar} 1/222].
For example, if someone says to you: [I thought I saw you writing yesterday.]{.trans}
To reply in the negative, you would say:
[مَا كُنْتُ أَكْتُبُ]{.ar}
instead of
[كُنْتُ لَا أَكْتُبُ]{.ar}
to mean [I was not writing.]{.trans}

The construction 
[مَا كَانَ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar}
is also used when one wishes to say that one never used to do something due to one's circumstances And also to mean that one did not know how to do something in the past.
For example,

[مَا كُنْتُ أَحْفَظُ شِعْرًا]{.ar}  
[I used to not memorize any poetry.]{.trans}

As for
[كَانَ لَا يَفْعَلُ]{.ar},
it connotes an intentional or purposeful lack of doing something.
Whereas, with
[مَا كَانَ يَفْعَلُ]{.ar},
the lack of action may be incidental.
For example,
[كَانَ لَا يَقْرَأُ ٱلْقُرْآنَ]{.ar} "He used to not read the Qurʾān imparts that the person was intentionally not doing so.
Whereas
[مَا كَانَ يَقْرَأُ ٱلْقُرْآنَ]{.ar} does not convey the intentionality of the lack of action. For example, the person may not have been reading the Qurʾān because he did not know how to.

### The combination [كَانَ يَكُونُ]{.ar}

Occasionally, 
[كَانَ]{.ar}
can be combined with its own stateful verb
[يَكُونُ]{.ar}
This gives the meaning [was being]{.trans} or [used to be]{.trans}.
[يَكُونُ]{.ar} is, in this combination, often optional and may be dropped for no change in meaning. Examples:

[كَانَ يَكُونُ فِي مِهْنَةِ أَهْلِهِ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :676](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:676)]{.citex}  
and  
[كَانَ فِي مِهْنَةِ أَهْلِهِ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :6039](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6039)]{.citex}  
[He used to keep himself busy serving his family]{.trans}

[قَدْ كَانَ يَكُونُ فِي الأُمَمِ مُحَدَّثُونَ]{.ar}
[[[جامع الترمذي]{.ar} :2398](https://sunnah.com/tirmidhi:2398)]{.citex}  
[There used to be in the nations inspired persons]{.trans}  

[رِجَالٌ كَانُوا يَكُونُونَ مَعَ ٱلْمُلُوكِ]{.ar}
[Wright 2/21C]{.citex}  
[men that used to be with the kings]{.trans}

[كَانَ يَكُونُ فِي ٱلْبَيْتِ]{.ar}
[Fischer 107]{.citex}  
[He used to be in the house.]{.trans}

### Possible occurrence

Sometimes
[كَانَ]{.ar}
is used with a stateful verb to express an action that could, should, or would have occurred. Examples:

[كَانَ يَكُونُ سُوءَ أَدَبٍ]{.ar}
[Fischer 108]{.citex}  
[It would have been a misbehavior.]{.trans}

[فَقَالَ حُذَيْفَةُ أَنْتَ كُنْتَ تَفْعَلُ ذَلِكَ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح مسلم]{.ar} :1788](https://sunnah.com/muslim:1788)]{.citex}  
[[#Hupayfah]{.trn2} said: 'You might have done that.']{.trans}  

This meaning can also be for the future, for example in a question:

[أَىَّ شَىْءٍ كُنْتَ تَصْنَعُ]{.ar}
[[[سنن ابن ماجه]{.ar} :2606](https://sunnah.com/ibnmajah:2606)]{.citex}  
[Which thing would you do?]{.trans}

### Omission of [كَانَ]{.ar}

If one or more perfect verbs precedes the stateful verb 
or if the context indicates that the action was occurring in the past, then
[كَانَ]{.ar}
can be omitted, and the stateful verb is used by itself.^[Wright 2/21C] For example:

[قُلْ فَلِمَ تَقْتُلُونَ أَنۢبِيَآءَ ٱللَّهِ مِن قَبْلُ]{.ar}
[[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:91](https://quran.com/2/91)]{.citex}  
[Say, ]{.trans}Then why did you kill the prophets of Allāh before"  
(No [كُنْتُمْ]{.ar} before [تَقْتُلُونَ]{.ar}.)

[وَٱتَّبَعُوا۟ مَا تَتْلُوا۟ ٱلشَّيَـٰطِينُ عَلَىٰ مُلْكِ سُلَيْمَـٰنَ ۖ]{.ar}
[[[سورة البقرة]{.ar} 2:102](https://quran.com/2/102)]{.citex}  
[And they followed [instead] what the devils had recited during the reign of Solomon]{.trans}  
(No [كَانَتْ]{.ar} before [تَتْلُو]{.ar}.)

### [كَانَ]{.ar} followed by a doer participle or doee participle instead of a stateful verb

Instead of a stateful verb after [كَانَ]{.ar}, its doer participle or doee participle may be used instead. 
And this can give the effect of a state of being rather than an action being done.
For example:

[كَانَ سَاكِنًا]{.ar}
[Wright 2/198A]{.citex}  
[He was dwelling]{.trans}

[كَانَتِ ٱلْعُصِيُّ مَرْكُوزَةً فِي ٱلْأَرْضِ]{.ar}
[Wright 2/198A]{.citex}  
[The staffs were sticking in the ground.]{.trans}  
([كَانَتْ تُرْكَزُ]{.ar} would imply that they were being stuck.)

When the verbal noun refers to an action taking place in the future, the idea of futurity is transferred to a past time. For example:

[أَمْرٌ كَانَ مَفْعُولًا]{.ar}
[Wright 2/196A]{.citex}  
[a matter which was to be done]{.trans}

## The perfect verb [كَانَ]{.ar} combined with a perfect verb

[كَانَ]{.ar}
is combined with a following perfect verb to denote 
an action completed prior to some past (specified or implied) point in time.
Example:

:::{.ar}
مَاتَ ٱلرَّشِيدُ بِطُوسَ وَكَانَ خَرَجَ إِلَىٰ خُرَاسَانَ لِمُحَارَبَةِ رَافِعِ بْنِ ٱللَّيْثِ
:::
[Wright 2/5C]{.citex}

[[al-#racId]{.trn2} died at [#TUs]{.trn2} after (literally: and) he had set out for [#xurAsAn]{.trn2} to combat [#rAfie ibn al-#layv]{.trn2}.]{.trans}


The particle [قَدْ]{.ar} is often used when
[كَانَ]{.ar} is combined with a perfect verb.
[قَدْ]{.ar}
may be placed either between
[كَانَ]{.ar}
and the following perfect verb, or before
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
Examples:

[كُنْتُ قَدْ رَبَّيْتُ جَارِيَةً]{.ar}
[Wright 2/5C]{.citex}  
<!--[[نوادر الكرام في الجاهلية والإسلام لإبراهيم زيدان]{.ar} p.\ 13]{.citex}  -->
[I had brought up a girl]{.trans}

[قَدْ كَانَتْ فَرَغَتْ مِنْ عَمَلِهَا]{.ar}  
[She had been done with her work.]{.trans}

When their are multiple perfect verbs, and one (or more) of them occurred
farther in the past than the others, it is indicated with 
[قَدْ]{.ar},
the others having merely
[كَانَ]{.ar}.
We re-use a previous example here and extend it:

:::{.ar}
مَاتَ ٱلرَّشِيدُ بِطُوسَ وَكَانَ خَرَجَ إِلَىٰ خُرَاسَانَ لِمُحَارَبَةِ رَافِعِ بْنِ ٱللَّيْثِ.
وَكَانَ رَافِعٌ هَـٰذَا قَدْ خَرَجَ وَخَلَعَ ٱلطَّاعَةَ وَتَغَلَّبَ عَلَىٰ سَمَرْقَنْدَ.
:::
[Wright 2/6A]{.citex}

"[al-#racId]{.trn2} died at [#TUs]{.trn2} after he had set out for [#xurAsAn]{.trn2} to combat [#rAfie ibn al-#layv]{.trn2}.
And this [#rAfie]{.trn2} had already rebelled and cast off his allegiance and taken forcible posession of Samarqand."  
(Note how 
[قَدْ]{.ar}
is only used before 
[#rAfie]{.trn2}'s action of rebelling.)


### Negation

This combination may, again, be negated in multiple ways. Examples:

[لاَ يَأْتِي ابْنَ آدَمَ النَّذْرُ بِشَىْءٍ لَمْ يَكُنْ قَدْ قَدَّرْتُهُ]{.ar}
[[[صحيح البخاري]{.ar} :6609](https://sunnah.com/bukhari:6609)]{.citex}  
[Vowing does not bring to the son of Adam anything I have not already written in his fate,]{.trans}

[وَدِدْتُ أَنِّي لَمْ أَكُنْ خَرَجْتُ الْعَامَ]{.ar}
[[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :1778](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:1778)]{.citex}  
[I wish I had not come out (for [#Hajj]{.trn2}) this year]{.trans}

[وَمَا كَانَ قَدْ أَتَاهَا بِشَيْءٍ]{.ar}
[A report narrated in [[إحياء علوم الدين لأبي حامد الغزالي]{.ar} 3/139](https://shamela.ws/book/9472/885) without a chain]{.citex}  
[And he had not brought her anything]{.trans}

## The stateful verb [يَكُونُ]{.ar} combined with a perfect verb

The stateful verb
[يَكُونُ]{.ar}
is compined with a perfect verb (often with an interposed [قَدْ]{.ar})
to express that the action is conceived of having been completed in the future.
Examples:

[يَكُونُ قَدْ وَجَبَ عَلَيْكَ صَدَقَةٌ]{.ar}
[[[مشكاة المصابيح]{.ar} :1793](https://sunnah.com/mishkat:1793)]{.citex}  
[Charity will have been incumbent upon you]{.trans}

[فَلْنَأْخُذْهُ فَنَكُونُ قَدْ أَخَْذْنَا عِوَضًا]{.ar}
[Fischer 108]{.citex}  
[Let us take him for (then) we will have taken a substitute]{.trans}

#### The a-state verb [يَكُونَ]{.ar} combined with a perfect verb

An a-state [يَكُونَ]{.ar} is combined with a perfect verb
to express being in a state of an action having occurred
or that might have occurred. For example:

[خَافَ أَنْ يَكُونَ قَدْ أَخْطَأَ]{.ar}
[Fischer 110]{.citex}  
[He feared that he could have erred.]{.trans}

[وَيَجُوزُ أَنْ يَكُونُوا سُبِقُوا]{.ar}
[[[المهذب فيما وقع في القرآن من المعرب للسيوطي]{.ar} p.\ 59](https://shamela.ws/book/26097/3)]{.citex}  
[And that they might have been preceded is possible]{.trans}

[يَشْتَرِطُ فِي ٱلنَّائِبِ أَنْ يَكُونَ قَدْ حَجَّ عَنْ نَفْسِهِ]{.ar}  
[It is conditional for the deputy that he be in as state of already having performed the [#Hajj]{.trn2} for himself.]{.trans}

## The verb of command [كُنْ]{.ar} combined with a stateful verb

Ocassionally,
the verb of command [كُنْ]{.ar} is combined with a stateful verb, thus:

[كُنْ أَنْتَ تُكَلِّمُهُمْ]{.ar}
[Fischer 121]{.citex}  
[You be speaking to them!]{.trans}

## [كَانَ]{.ar} with the [ل]{.ar} of denial

One special use of 
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
is what is termed the
[ل]{.ar}
_of denial_.
This is a negative 
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
(either
[مَا كَانَ]{.ar} 
or
[لَمْ يَكُنْ]{.ar} with the appropriate suffixes or prefixes for the subject)
followed by [لِ]{.ar}
and then an a-state stateful verb.
This expresses the meaning of:

 i. to deny being the one to do something, or 
ii. to deny going to do something

Here are some examples:

[لَمْ تَكُنْ زَيْنَبُ لِتَضْرِبَ وَلَدَهَا]{.ar}  
[Zaynab was not one to beat her child.]{.trans}  
or  
[Zaynab was not going to beat her child.]{.trans}  

[وَمَا كَانَ ٱللَّهُ لِيُعَذِّبَهُمْ وَأَنتَ فِيهِمْ ۚ]{.ar}
[[[سورة الأنفال]{.ar} 8:33](https://quran.com/8/33)]{.citex}  
[But Allāh would not punish them while you, [O Muḥammad], are among them]{.trans}  

[فَقَالَ أَتَخْشَيْنَ أَنْ أَقْتُلَهُ مَا كُنْتُ لأَفْعَلَ ذَلِكَ]{.ar}
[[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :3112](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:3112)]{.citex}  
[He said: Do you fear that I shall kill him ? I am not going to do that.]{.trans}  

[قَالَ لَمْ أَكُنْ لأَفْعَلَ]{.ar}
[[[سنن ابن ماجه]{.ar} :1503](https://sunnah.com/ibnmajah:1503)]{.citex}  
[He said: I was not going to do that.]{.trans}

## [كَانَ]{.ar} with the [ل]{.ar} of deserving

Closely related, yet distinct from, 
the use of
[كَانَ]{.ar} with the [ل]{.ar} of denial
(above)
is 
the use of
[كَانَ]{.ar} with a [ل]{.ar} that signifies deserving, behooving, appropriateness, or possibility.
This is, again, a negative 
[كَانَ]{.ar} 
followed by the preposition [لِ]{.ar}
and a following i-state noun,
and then [أَنْ]{.ar} followed by an a-state stateful verb.
This signifies that the action of the verb does not behoove, or is not appropriate or desrving or possibly for the person denoted by the noun after [لِ]{.ar}.^[[[البحر المحيط لأبي حيان]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/albahr-almuheet/3/79/) and [[تفسير ابن عاشور]{.ar}](https://tafsir.app/ibn-aashoor/3/79) for [سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:79]
For example:

[فَأَنۢبَتْنَا بِهِۦ حَدَآئِقَ ذَاتَ بَهْجَةٍۢ مَّا كَانَ لَكُمْ أَن تُنۢبِتُوا۟ شَجَرَهَآ ۗ]{.ar}
[[[سورة النمل]{.ar} 27:60](https://quran.com/27/60)]{.citex}  
[causing to grow thereby gardens of joyful beauty which you could not [otherwise] have grown the trees thereof]{.trans}  

[مَا كَانَ لِبَشَرٍ أَن يُؤْتِيَهُ ٱللَّهُ ٱلْكِتَـٰبَ وَٱلْحُكْمَ وَٱلنُّبُوَّةَ ثُمَّ يَقُولَ لِلنَّاسِ كُونُوا۟ عِبَادًۭا لِّى مِن دُونِ ٱللَّهِ]{.ar}
[[[سورة آل عمران]{.ar} 3:79](https://quran.com/3/79)]{.citex}  
[It is not for a human [prophet] that Allāh should give him the Scripture and authority and prophethood and then he would say to the people, 'Be servants to me rather than Allāh,']{.trans}

[قَالَ أَبُو بَكْرٍ مَا كَانَ لاِبْنِ أَبِي قُحَافَةَ أَنْ يُصَلِّيَ بَيْنَ يَدَىْ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ صلى الله عليه وسلم]{.ar}
[[[سنن أبي داود]{.ar} :940](https://sunnah.com/abudawud:940)]{.citex}  
[[#abU]{.trn2} Bakr said ; it was not befitting for the son of [#abU #quHAfah]{.trn2} to lead the prayer in the presence of the Messenger of [#allAh]{.trn2} [ﷺ]{.aralt}]{.trans}
